Goals for Chapter 37 • To understand the two postulates of relativity and their motivation • To see why two observers can disagree on simultaneity • To learn why moving clocks run slow • To see how motion affects length • To understand why velocity depends on the frame of reference • To calculate relativistic momentum and kinetic energy • To explore the key concepts of general relativity Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. Introduction • How do particles behave if they reach 99.995% the speed of light? • What are the basic postulates behind special relativity? • We shall see some of the far- reaching implications of relativity, such as the effect of motion on time and length. • We’ll see that momentum and kinetic energy must be redefined. Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. Einstein’s first postulate • Einstein’s first postulate, known as the principle of relativity, states that the laws of physics are the same in every inertial reference frame. (See Figure 37.1 below.) Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. Einstein’s second postulate • Einstein’s second postulate is that the speed of light in vacuum is the same in all inertial frames of reference and is independent of the motion of the source. (See Figure 37.2 below.) • The second postulate implies that it is impossible for an inertial observer to travel at the speed of light in vacuum. Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. The Galilean transformation • The Galilean transformation is a transformation between two inertial frames of reference. • Follow the text discussion of the Galilean transformation. Use Figure 37.3 at the right, in which the position of particle P is described in two frames of reference. Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. Relativity of time intervals • The two observers (Mavis and Stanley) measure different time intervals due to their relative motion. (See Figure 37.6 below.) • Follow the text discussion of the relativity of time intervals and time dilation. Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. Proper time • Proper time is the time interval between two events that occur at the same point. • A frame of reference can be pictured as a coordinate system with a grid of synchronized clocks, as in Figure 37.9 at the right. Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. Relativistic momentum • Follow the text discussion of relativistic momentum. • Figure 37.20 at the right shows a graph of the momentum of a particle as a function of its speed. Notice that the momentum approaches infinity as the speed approaches the speed of light. Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. Newton’s second law and relativistic mass • Follow the text discussion of Newton’s second law and relativistic mass. • The relativistic mass is mrel = m. • Follow Example 37.9 which looks at the relativistic dynamics of an electron. Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. Relativistic work and energy • The relativistic kinetic energy is K = ( – 1)mc2. The graph in Figure 37.21 (right) shows the kinetic energy as a function of speed. Note that the kinetic energy approaches infinity as the speed approaches the speed of light. • The rest energy is mc2. • The total energy of a particle is E = K + mc2 = mc2. • The total energy, rest energy, and momentum are related by E2 = (mc2)2 + (pc)2.
